location: The same. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.

lines.text: Music. Tables set out: Servants attending.  Enter divers Lords, Senators and others, at several doors

lines.speaker: first lord
lines.text: The good time of day to you, sir.

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: I also wish it to you. I think this honourable lord did but try us this other day.

lines.speaker: first lord
lines.text: Upon that were my thoughts tiring, when we encountered: I hope it is not so low with him as he made it seem in the trial of his several friends.

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: It should not be, by the persuasion of his new feasting.

lines.speaker: first lord
lines.text: I should think so: he hath sent me an earnest inviting, which many my near occasions did urge me to put off; but he hath conjured me beyond them, and I must needs appear.

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: In like manner was I in debt to my importunate business, but he would not hear my excuse. I am sorry, when he sent to borrow of me, that my provision was out.

lines.speaker: first lord
lines.text: I am sick of that grief too, as I understand how all things go.

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: Every man here's so. What would he have borrowed of you?

lines.speaker: first lord
lines.text: A thousand pieces.

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: A thousand pieces!

lines.speaker: first lord
lines.text: What of you?

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: He sent to me, sir,--Here he comes.
Enter TIMON and Attendants

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: With all my heart, gentlemen both; and how fare you?

lines.speaker: first lord
lines.text: Ever at the best, hearing well of your lordship.

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: The swallow follows not summer more willing than we your lordship.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: [Aside]  Nor more willingly leaves winter; such summer-birds are men. Gentlemen, our dinner will not recompense this long stay: feast your ears with the music awhile, if they will fare so harshly o' the trumpet's sound; we shall to 't presently.

lines.speaker: first lord
lines.text: I hope it remains not unkindly with your lordship that I returned you an empty messenger.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: O, sir, let it not trouble you.

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: My noble lord,--

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: Ah, my good friend, what cheer?

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: My most honourable lord, I am e'en sick of shame, that, when your lordship this other day sent to me, I was so unfortunate a beggar.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: Think not on 't, sir.

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: If you had sent but two hours before,--

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: Let it not cumber your better remembrance. Come, bring in all together.
The banquet brought in

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: All covered dishes!

lines.speaker: first lord
lines.text: Royal cheer, I warrant you.

lines.speaker: third lord
lines.text: Doubt not that, if money and the season can yield it.

lines.speaker: first lord
lines.text: How do you? What's the news?

lines.speaker: third lord
lines.text: Alcibiades is banished: hear you of it?

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: Alcibiades banished!

lines.speaker: third lord
lines.text: 'Tis so, be sure of it.

lines.speaker: first lord
lines.text: How! how!

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: I pray you, upon what?

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: My worthy friends, will you draw near?

lines.speaker: third lord
lines.text: I'll tell you more anon. Here's a noble feast toward.

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: This is the old man still.

lines.speaker: third lord
lines.text: Will 't hold? will 't hold?

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: It does: but time will--and so--

lines.speaker: third lord
lines.text: I do conceive.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: Each man to his stool, with that spur as he would to the lip of his mistress: your diet shall be in all places alike. Make not a city feast of it, to let the meat cool ere we can agree upon the first place: sit, sit. The gods require our thanks. You great benefactors, sprinkle our society with thankfulness. For your own gifts, make yourselves praised: but reserve still to give, lest your deities be despised. Lend to each man enough, that one need not lend to another; for, were your godheads to borrow of men, men would forsake the gods. Make the meat be beloved more than the man that gives it. Let no assembly of twenty be without a score of villains: if there sit twelve women at the table, let a dozen of them be--as they are. The rest of your fees, O gods--the senators of Athens, together with the common lag of people--what is amiss in them, you gods, make suitable for destruction. For these my present friends, as they are to me nothing, so in nothing bless them, and to nothing are they welcome. Uncover, dogs, and lap.
The dishes are uncovered and seen to be full of warm water

lines.speaker: some speak
lines.text: What does his lordship mean?

lines.speaker: some others
lines.text: I know not.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: May you a better feast never behold, You knot of mouth-friends I smoke and lukewarm water Is your perfection. This is Timon's last; Who, stuck and spangled with your flatteries, Washes it off, and sprinkles in your faces Your reeking villany. Live loathed and long, Most smiling, smooth, detested parasites, Courteous destroyers, affable wolves, meek bears, You fools of fortune, trencher-friends, time's flies, Cap and knee slaves, vapours, and minute-jacks! Of man and beast the infinite malady Crust you quite o'er! What, dost thou go? Soft! take thy physic first--thou too--and thou;-- Stay, I will lend thee money, borrow none. What, all in motion? Henceforth be no feast, Whereat a villain's not a welcome guest. Burn, house! sink, Athens! henceforth hated be Of Timon man and all humanity!
Throwing the water in their faces
Throws the dishes at them, and drives them out
Exit
Re-enter the Lords, Senators,  and c

lines.speaker: first lord
lines.text: How now, my lords!

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: Know you the quality of Lord Timon's fury?

lines.speaker: third lord
lines.text: Push! did you see my cap?

lines.speaker: fourth lord
lines.text: I have lost my gown.

lines.speaker: first lord
lines.text: He's but a mad lord, and nought but humour sways him. He gave me a jewel th' other day, and now he has beat it out of my hat: did you see my jewel?

lines.speaker: third lord
lines.text: Did you see my cap?

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: Here 'tis.

lines.speaker: fourth lord
lines.text: Here lies my gown.

lines.speaker: first lord
lines.text: Let's make no stay.

lines.speaker: second lord
lines.text: Lord Timon's mad.

lines.speaker: third lord
lines.text: I feel 't upon my bones.

lines.speaker: fourth lord
lines.text: One day he gives us diamonds, next day stones.
Exeunt
